body: "At any political meeting, nine-tenths of the questions from the homeowners are about multifamily housing,'' says Hy Sardy, chairman of the Midwood Development Corporation in Brooklyn. When homeowners live in areas that have high concentrations of rental housing, preservation of the quality of the rental stock becomes a major concern. Accordingly,
title: HOMEOWNERS WORKING TO IMPROVE RENTAL PROPERTY

body: When the Oceanfront Development Corporation, a local community organization in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, sought help to upgrade the Neptune Avenue commercial district last year, it contacted the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, the voluntary charitable agency. The federation responded by helping the community group
title: CHARITABLE GROUP FIGHTS CITY DECAY

body: The ''triple crown'' is what the players from St. John the Baptist of West Islip, L.I., were calling this year's Metro Bowl game. The Catholic High Schools Football League champions ran away with the title for the the third straight year as they defeated John Adams, the Public Schools Athletic League champion, 27-16, yesterday at Midwood Field in
title: ST. JOHN THE BAPTIST WINS METRO BOWL

body: James Madison High School of Brooklyn won its second Public Schools Athletic Association B Division title with a 36-8 victory over previously undefeated Far Rockaway. Madison, which lost two of its first three games this season, finished with seven straight victories. The Golden Knights, who last won the title in 1977, will play Maria Regina of the
title: JOHN ADAMS AND MADISON CAPTURE P.S.A.L. TITLES

body: Bayside High School of Queens, which had won the Public Schools Athletic League Division A the last three years, was eliminated in the semifinal round yesterday, 22-13, by undefeated Susan Wagner. Wagner will play for the championship against Adams, the Queens regular-season champion, which topped Lehman of the Bronx, 33-6, in another semifinal in
title: Wagner, Adams Gain

body: Adams, Susan Wagner, Lehman and Bayside, the latter two scoring upsets, were victorious in the quarterfinals of the Public Schools Athletic League A Division playoffs. Adams defeated New Dorp, 40-6, while Susan Wagner was a 30-6 winner over Kennedy. Lehman rallied in the final quarter to oust Midwood by 13-6. Bayside, winner of the last three
title: ADAMS, WAGNER, LEHMAN AND BAYSIDE ADVANCED

body: Numerical Proliferation B uildings along two blocks of 94th and 95th Streets between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue are getting highly visible street addresses painted on their backs. The aim is quick, precise identification when a neighbor sees a fire, burglary or other emergency. Sponsored by the two block associations, the foot-high
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Bayside, the P.S.A.L. champions for the last three seasons, squeaked into this year's playoffs by scoring all of its points after intermission in a 34-0 victory over Beach Channel in a decisive Queens A division game. Richie Kaval, the Commodores' junior running back, broke the scoreless tie by scoring the first of his two touchdowns on a 4-yard
title: BAYSIDE WINS BY 34-0 TO GAIN PLAYOFF SPOT

body: After being stung by a 15-yard first-period field goal by Steve Sharpe, Jefferson roared back to down Lafayette, 36-11, and knock the Redmen from the ranks of the undefeated in the Brooklyn A-Division battle for first place. Ricky Johnson, a 5-foot-10-inch, 190-pound junior fullback, was a key figure in the rout for Jefferson. He ran for a career
title: JEFFERSON DEFEATS LAFAYETTE

body: Boxing Hilmer Kenty vs. Roberto Elizondo, 10 rounds, lightweights; Mauricio Bravo vs. Pablo Baez, 10 rounds, welterweights, from Americana Hotel, McAfee, N.J. Kenty, the former World Boxing Association champion now ranked No. 3, has lost once in 23 fights and has returned to action after a retina operation. Elizondo, 24-3, is ranked eighth.
title: SUNDAY SPORTS

body: Baseball World Series: Brewers vs. St. Louis Cardinals, game five, at County Stadium, Milwaukee. The first-game starters, Mike Caldwell of Milwaukee and Bob Forsch, will oppose each other. Caldwell won the first meeting, 10-0. (Television - Channel 4, 4 P.M. Radio - WCBS, 880; 4 P.M.) Boxing James Broad vs. Danny Long, at Atlantic City,
title: SUNDAYSPORTS

body: Bayside, the defending Public Schools Athletic League champion, has fallen on hard times. First it lost its star quarterback, Kevin Harmon, who underwent knee surgery after being injured last week. Now Bayside has lost its first league game, bowing by 8-0 to John Adams in Queens A Division play. Tommy Emma, a senior split end for the Spartans,
title: Bayside Loses to Adams, 8-0

body: Darnell Ethridge of John F. Kennedy High in the Bronx, is almost certain to become a 1,000-yard rusher before the end of the season, but while the DeWitt Clinton defense was keying on him yesterday, his teammate, Vernon Parker, was doing most of the damage as the Knights shut out the Governors, 28-0. The Governors held Ethridge to 42 yards rushing,
title: PARKER OF KENNEDY PLAYS THE KEY ROLE IN ROUT OF CLINTON

body: TO make his point, Morris Gartenstein reached into the animal world.' 'It's like you're holding a tiger by the tail,'' he said. ''You c an't let it go and you can't pull it back.'' The tiger is a piece of vacant land behind a fence at East 29th Street and Avenue J in the Midwood section of Brooklyn. The Gartenstein family, builders mainly in the
title: SPOT BUILDER IS TREADING WATER

body: Baseball California Angels vs. Brewers at Milwaukee, Game 5 of American League championship series, (Television - Channel 7, 4 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880; 4 P.M.) St. Louis Cardinals vs. Braves at Atlanta, Game 3 of National League championship series, (Television -Channel 7, 8 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880; 8 P.M.) Boxing Milt McCrory vs. Victor Abraham, 10
title: SUNDAYSPORTS

body: John Bradford hears the passengers talking on the bus he drives from Co-Op City to midtown. He hears people say how selfish the football players are, how needless the strike is. ''Even if I'm not in the conversation, sometimes I butt in,'' Bradford says. ''I tell people the players deserve more money.'' Bradford plays the game for free these days,
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; THE ONLY GAME IN TOWN

body: Jefferson's Orange Wave, led by the fullback Ricky Johnson and the tailback Anthony Simpson, racked up 298 yards of total offense, all of it on the ground, to trounce Lincoln, 30-0, on the loser's field. Johnson had 102 yards on 10 carries, including touchdown runs of 3 and 1 yards. Simpson did not score, but carried the ball 16 times for 90 yards.
title: JEFFERSON TROUNCES LINCOLN

body: Except for a tree in its small entrance courtyard that rises nearly to the roof, there appears to be nothing outstanding about the newly renovated, four-story apartment building at 1554 Ocean Avenue in Brooklyn's Midwood neighborhood. It seems just one of the many residential apartment houses that line the five-mile thoroughfare from Park Slope
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; BROOKLYN BUILDING IS RENOVATED UNDER CITY PROGRAM

body: New Utrecht of Brooklyn, which had not won an opening game since 1975, visited Staten Island yesterday and returned home with a 25-14 victory over Curtis in a nonleague Public Schools Athletic League contest. It was a happy debut for John Burke as head coach of the Utes. He formerly coached at Tilden. It appeared as if New Utrecht's opening-game
title: UTRECHT TRIUMPHES

body: Citizens' crime-watching groups, scattered and isolated 10 years ago, have now enlisted more than five million members and are gaining recognition from the police and other experts as a highly effective force against crime. Often operating with direct channels to police departments, the groups patrol their neighborhoods in radio-equipped cars, walk
title: ANTICRIME PATROLS GROW IN NUMBER AND EFFECT

body: Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola has upheld the disputed action of Community School Board 22 in Brooklyn in appointing a new principal for Public School 193 in the Midwood area. The appointment of Kathleen Shay, director of a citywide remedial program for fourth-graders, was opposed by a portion of the P.S. 193 Parents' Association. THE CITY
title: THE CITY; Macchiarola Backs Board on Principal

body: Five men were arrested in New Jersey yesterday after driving through the Holland Tunnel in two vans loaded with about $10,000 worth of stolen meat, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said. Kenneth Walton, deputy assistant director of the F.B.I.'s New York office, said agents had watched the suspects unload the meat from a truck parked at 10th
title: THE CITY; F.B.I. Seizes 5 With Stolen Meat

body: Back to Brooklyn, Where a Career Began S he graduated from Brooklyn's James Madison High School with an NBC contract in her pocket and went on to an international operatic and show-business career. But Elaine Malbin, quick to say ''I was a plain little old Brooklyn girl,'' was back last night at Midwood Field - near the Flatbush home of her
title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY

body: Four Concerts Planned By Brooklyn Philharmonic Music continues to blossom in Brooklyn's parks with four pops concerts Wednesday through Sunday with the Brooklyn Philharmonic conducted by Bruce Ferden. Featuring music from the operatic repertory designed to lift limp spirits, Mr. Ferden will conduct the soprano Elaine Malbin in arias by Puccini,
title: BRIEFS ON THE ARTS

body: A recent dispute over the appointment of a principal for a Brooklyn elementary school has focused attention on the process of selecting local school administrators under the city's decentralized school system. The naming of Kathleen Shay, a 34-year-old administrator of a remedial-school program, to be principal of Public School 193 in the Midwood
title: PARENTS' ROLE IN HIRING OF PRINCIPAL DISPUTED

body: To the Editor: There is a wrong perception being promoted that the J-51 program has only the support of the real estate entrepreneurs and does not benefit the tenants and the communities. his is wrong. The J-51 program is an essential tool when doing gut rehabilitation of deteriorating buildings in neighborhoods such as Boro Park, Kensington,
title: J-51 HELPS TENANTS AND NEIGHBORHOODS

body: ANYONE who doubts that the man at the top can establish the tone and personality of a giant corporation might well consider the Waldbaum supermarket chain. Having only limited confidence in such modern business instruments as formal market research, Ira Waldbaum, the 54-year-old president of the chain, is a consummate pragmatist. He and his
title: A SUPERMARKET BOSS WITH A MOM-AND-POP PHILOSOPHY

body: IN addition to the Great Irish Fair in Brooklyn, streets and parks all over town will be alive this weekend with music, dance and other amusements. The largest of the fairs is the fifth annual Queens Day, a celebration that begins Sunday at 9:30 A.M. at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park and concludes hours later with a concert by the Queens Symphony
title: QUEENS DAY LEADS A WEEKEND FULL OF FAIRS

body: New York City detectives are searching for at least three more personsthe police believe terrorized and robbed dozens of people in two separate incidents on Long Island late Friday and early Saturday, the New York City police said yesterday. Three suspects were arrested Saturday morning after a shootout with the police in the East New York section
title: 3 OTHERS SOUGHT FOR QUESTIONING ON L.I. ATTACKS

body: Over the last five years, the Borough Park section of Brooklyn has become one of the most ambitious centers of residential real estate activity in the city. According to specialists in property sales and mortgage loans, land prices have soared as contractors buy old frame houses on side streets off the main avenues, demolish them and build new
title: HOUSING SURGE ALTERS BOROUGH PARK

body: A total of 1,800 high school seniors from throughout the country have been named winners of $1,000 scholarships in the 26th annual competition sponsored by the National Merit Scholarship Corporation. The $1,000 winners, selected in proportion to each state's percentage of the nation's total graduating high school seniors, were chosen from 13,500
title: WINNERS OF $1,000 MERIT SCHOLARSHIPS NAMED

body: The marriage of Dr. Marcia Dale Kass to David Myles Waitzman took place yesterday at the East Midwood Jewish Center in Brooklyn. Rabbi Alvin Kass, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Dr. Elaine Kass of Brooklyn and Dr. Morton Kass of Paterson, N.J. Her mother is assistant professor of clinical pediatrics at the
title: DR. MARCIA DALE KASS WED TO DAVID M. WAITZMAN

body: Intrigued by the symbols used to represent ideas, Reena Beth Gordon began a project last July to determine how English was understood when spoken. Relying on research in mathematical linguistics, the 16-year-old senior at Midwood High School in Brooklyn designed a system that predicted how ambiguous adverb-verb sentence structures would be
title: Headliners; Doublespeak

body: New York City students won the top three prizes today in the annual Westinghouse Science Talent Search, one of the most prestigious competitions in the nation for teen-age scientists. Reena Beth Gordon of Brooklyn, who worked eight months on an experiment involving mathematics and linguistics, was awarded the first-place $12,000 scholarship. Miss
title: CITY'S STUDENTS WIN TOP 3 PRIZES IN A NATIONAL SCIENCE COMPETITION

body: The players took some strange detours before the nation's highestscoring college basketball team was assembled on the northwest corner of Flatbush and DeKalb Avenues -in the old Brooklyn Paramount Theater, where the biggest motion pictures played and Frank Sinatra sang in person. A few cases of homesickness, a player and a coach unable to get along
title: THEY CAME HOME TO L.I.U.

body: This Thursday, Feb. 4, at the Dorothy Chandler Pavillion in Los Angeles, the flutist James Galway will step before the Los Angeles Philharmonic and retell in music the legend of the Pied Piper of Hamelin. The music is by the American composer John Corigliano, and it is like no other flute concerto you have heard before. First, bursts of orchestral
title: HIGHBROW MUSIC TO HUM

body: An article in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday omitted the name of a Midwood High School student in Brooklyn who was chosen as a finalist in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search. She is Reena B. Gordon.
title: CORRECTION

body: New York City housing officials and a consortium of 13 city banks have established a $6 .5 million rehabilitation loan program to aid housing renov ation in 33 city neighborhoods. The program will combine $1.5 million in Federal funds with $5 million from the banks to provide re habilitation funds to qualified applicants at below-market interest
title: ABOUT REAL ESTATE; KEY HOUSING PROGRAM REVIVED IN CITY
